visual_elements.description: A table defining 'Grade' based on 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It has three rows of data, each describing a different measurement context for 'Grade'.

Figure 44: 'Existing vs. Finished grade'. This diagram illustrates a house on a sloped lot. It shows the 'Existing grade (before fill)' as a dashed line and 'Finished grade (after fill)' as a solid line. An arrow indicates 'Height: measured to top of roof material of the highest peak'. Another arrow points to the 'Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure'. The house has a chimney and multiple windows.

Figure 45: 'Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%'. This diagram shows two houses on a steep slope. It illustrates two height limits: '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished'. The text states, 'The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope'. Arrows indicate 'Height' from the ground to the roof peak for both houses. 'Existing grade (before fill)' is also indicated.

Figure 46: 'Comparison of different grades'. This is a line chart with a grid, showing different slope ratios and their corresponding percentages. Lines are labeled '10:10 100%', '5:10 50%', '3:10 33%', and '1:10 10%'. The lines originate from a common point on the right and extend upwards and to the left.

additional_notes: The word 'materoal' in 'Height: measured to top of roof materoal of the highest peak' in Fig 44 appears to be a typo and should likely be 'material'.
The text 'Existing grade b' in Fig 44 is incomplete and appears to be cut off, likely 'Existing grade (before fill)' as seen in Fig 45.

qualifiers.text: at any point of the structure
at the midpoint of the building
at the closest point on the abutting site
The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

conditions.text: The height of a structure on land with natural slope ≤ 10%
The height of a structure on land with natural slope > 10%

logical_relationships.expression: IF 'The height of a structure on land with natural slope ≤ 10%' THEN 'Grade is defined as the lowest point of adjacent ground elevation prior to grading or fill' (q1 applies)

IF 'The height of a structure on land with natural slope > 10%' THEN 'Grade is defined as the adjacent ground elevation of the finished or existing grade, whichever is lower--at any point of the structure' (q2, q3 apply)
IF 'A daylight plane' THEN 'Grade is defined as the average of the grade at the midpoint of the building and the grade at the closest point on the abutting site' (q4, q5 apply)
The structure must comply with the lower of (30' above existing grade AND 30' above finished) at all points along the slope (q6 applies)

execution_sequence.action: Determine the natural slope of the land for the structure.
If natural slope is ≤ 10%, define 'Grade' as the lowest point of adjacent ground elevation prior to grading or fill for each building or structure.
If natural slope is > 10%, define 'Grade' as the adjacent ground elevation of the finished or existing grade, whichever is lower, at any point of the structure.
For a daylight plane, define 'Grade' as the average of the grade at the midpoint of the building and the grade at the closest point on the abutting site.
For structures on slopes greater than 10%, calculate two height limits: 30' above existing grade and 30' above finished grade.
The structure must comply with the lower of the two calculated height limits (30' above existing grade and 30' above finished) at all points along the slope.
